diagnoses: Drug Reactions (e.g., Antibiotics, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Reactive thrombocytosis due to inflammation or infection
Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as nephritis, acute pericarditis, and atrophic scarring. Seizures and synovitis can also be manifestations due to widespread inflammation and autoimmune activity.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing joint inflammation and synovitis, systemic involvement can lead to atrophic scarring. Seizures are less common and may occur secondary to medications or systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD can present with signs of synovitis, nephritis, and acute pericarditis. Neurological symptoms and atrophic scarring can also be observed due to its systemic nature.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is characterized by granulomas that might cause nephritis and atrophic scarring. Acute pericarditis and neurosarcoidosis can explain seizure presentations, whereas synovitis may occur.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s) could lead to nephritis and other systemic symptoms. Seizures might result from CNS involvement. Synovitis and atrophic scarring could also be manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This vasculitis can cause atrophic scarring and acute pericarditis. Neurological involvement might lead to seizures, and arthritis (synovitis) is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Late-stage Lyme disease can manifest with arthritis (including synovitis), rare cases of nephritis, and neurological symptoms that could potentially include seizures. Dermatological manifestations may somewhat resemble atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder is known to cause a wide range of symptoms that could theoretically include seizures (due to cerebral venous thrombosis), nephritis, and potentially pericarditis. Less clearly linked to synovitis and atrophic scarring but possible.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis)
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to a broad range of symptoms including nephritis and acute pericarditis. Seizures might occur due to CNS involvement. Synovitis and atrophic scarring could also manifest in certain stages or as complications.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Extrapulmonary TB can cause widespread systemic issues, including nephritis and potentially acute pericarditis. CNS involvement could lead to seizures. Joint involvement (synovitis) and atrophic scarring can be a result of the chronic inflammatory response.

diagnoses: Sjögren's Syndrome with renal and hematologic manifestations
Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma) with renal involvement and autoimmune hemolysis
Lupus Nephritis with secondary hematological abnormalities
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Drug-induced lupus erythematosus with renal and hematological manifestations
Vasculitis with renal involvement and pericardial effusion (e.g., ANCA-associated vasculitis)
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) with autoimmune cytopenias and pericardial effusion
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, severe COVID-19)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever, affecting the heart, joints, skin, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and joint pain. Some people have only one episode of adult Still's disease. In other people, the condition persists or recurs.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause erythema migrans (annular rash), joint pain, and neurologic complications.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory reaction that occurs in response to an infection in another part of your body. It typically causes inflammation in the joints, urinary tract, and eyes.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium (the fibrous sac surrounding the heart) often caused by a viral infection.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by a tick. It is life-threatening and most often causes fever, headache, rash, and can cause skin necrosis and gangrene of extremities.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by granulomas (clusters of inflammatory cells) in multiple organs, potentially affecting the heart, skin, joints, and nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Whipple's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare bacterial infection that primarily affects the small intestines but can also cause joint pain and skin manifestations.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus, Chikungunya)
Gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., Celiac disease, Crohn's disease)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis leading to transient hyperthyroidism
Thyroid Cancer with cervical lymph node involvement

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. This reaction could lead to angioedema and possibly affects electrolyte balance in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It's associated with abnormal immune findings and can lead to disturbances in body function, indirectly affecting electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Renal disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease and acute kidney failure can lead to abnormal electrolytes. They can indirectly cause dry eyes due to changes in fluid balance and may contribute to angioedema due to fluid retention.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic ketoacidosis
diagnoses.description: A serious diabetes complication where the body produces excess blood acids (ketones). This condition causes significant electrolyte imbalances and could indirectly cause dry eyes and other symptoms due to dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Eczema
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's chronic and can lead to oitis externa in severe cases. Eczema might be related to dry skin complications, including the presence of tags.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune skin condition, characterized by red, itchy, and scaly patches. People with psoriasis may experience angioedema as part of their symptoms and might develop skin tags in affected areas.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: Dehydration occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions. It can lead to dry eyes, abnormal electrolytes, and other related symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammation of the skin that occurs from contact with an allergen or irritating substance. It can lead to oitis externa and possibly eczematous tags.

diagnoses.name: Lymphedema
diagnoses.description: A condition of localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system, which can sometimes present as angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly. It frequently causes angioedema, and during the event, abnormal electrolytes may be noted due to the profound physiological disturbances it causes.

diagnoses: Allergic rhinitis (as a contributor to dysosmia)
Anxiety disorders (can contribute to or exacerbate gastrointestinal symptoms, physical sensitivities, and irritability)
Major depressive disorder (can present with somatic symptoms including gastroesophageal reflux, physical sensitivities)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can cause a wide range of symptoms including anxiety, leukopenia (low white blood cell count), and osteopenia (low bone density). Lupus can also affect the lungs, potentially leading to wheezing, and disrupt metabolism, sometimes resulting in hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.reason: Certain types of anemia, especially those related to vitamin deficiencies or autoimmune disorders, could hypothetically cause or coexist with conditions leading to these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Insufficiency
diagnoses.reason: This condition, which includes Addison's disease, can cause hypoglycemia, anxiety, and may be associated with other symptoms due to its effect on the balance of hormones, including those that regulate the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Overactivity of the parathyroid glands can lead to osteopenia and indirectly contribute to symptoms of anxiety and hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.reason: While primarily associated with wheezing and respiratory symptoms, severe or chronically unmanaged asthma can have systemic effects that might indirectly contribute to symptoms like anxiety. However, it’s less directly associated with leukopenia, hypoglycemia, or osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reason: COPD can lead to wheezing and, over time, can cause systemic inflammation that might indirectly relate to some of these other symptoms, though it is not a primary cause of leukopenia, hypoglycemia, or osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: HIV infection can cause leukopenia due to its impact on the immune system. Anxiety and osteopenia are also common in people living with HIV/AIDS. Hypoglycemia is less commonly directly associated but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reason: Chronic kidney disease could cause a range of metabolic disturbances including hypoglycemia and contributes to bone density loss. It can also cause a degree of anxiety and has been associated with respiratory symptoms in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.reason: This genetic condition often causes respiratory symptoms including wheezing. It can also lead to diabetes (and thus, potentially, hypoglycemia), osteopenia due to malabsorption, and present challenges that contribute to anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting metabolism and therefore potentially leading to symptoms like hypoglycemia, severe or untreated hypothyroidism can also contribute to anxiety, osteopenia, and, albeit less directly, leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Turner syndrome, a condition that affects only females, results when one of the X chromosomes (sex chromosomes) is missing or partially missing. It can lead to a variety of medical and developmental problems, including short height, failure of the ovaries to develop and infertility.

diagnoses.name: Usher Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Usher syndrome is a condition characterized by partial or total hearing loss and vision loss that worsens over time. This condition also affects balance and spatial orientation. It is a genetic condition that affects both hearing and vision.

diagnoses.name: Stickler Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Stickler syndrome is a genetic disorder that can cause serious vision, hearing, and joint problems, as well as unique facial characteristics. It can sometimes include complications with swallowing (dysphagia).

diagnoses.name: Pendred Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Pendred syndrome is a genetic disorder leading to developmental disorder of the bone in the inner ear and thyroid gland, resulting in hearing loss and goiter. It's one of the leading genetic causes of congenital deafness.

diagnoses.name: Treacher Collins Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Treacher Collins syndrome is a condition that affects the development of bones and other tissues of the face and can lead to hearing loss, problems with facial bones, and airway obstruction.

diagnoses.name: 22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome
diagnoses.description: 22q11.2 deletion syndrome is a disorder caused by a small missing piece of the 22nd chromosome. It can result in a wide range of health problems including heart defects, immune system deficiencies, cleft palate, and issues with feeding and swallowing (dysphagia).

diagnoses.name: Fragile X Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Fragile X syndrome is a genetic condition causing intellectual disability, behavioral and learning challenges and various physical characteristics. Though less common, it can include symptoms like obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition affecting males, caused by an extra X chromosome. Symptoms include infertility and smaller than normal testicles.

diagnoses.name: Waardenburg Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Waardenburg syndrome is a group of genetic conditions that can lead to hearing loss and changes in coloring (pigmentation) of the hair, skin, and eyes. Although hearing loss is a common symptom, it doesn't typically involve dysphagia or OCD behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Crouzon Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Crouzon syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the premature joining of certain bones of the skull during development, which affects the shape of the head and face. It may lead to hearing loss but does not typically cause infertility or dysphagia.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to symptoms such as dyspnea, wheezing, hypotension, and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Asthma attack
diagnoses.description: An exacerbation of asthma can cause wheezing, dyspnea, and may indirectly contribute to abdominal cramps due to severe coughing spells.

diagnoses.name: Addisonian crisis
diagnoses.description: A potentially life-threatening condition due to an acute adrenal insufficiency. Symptoms can include hypotension, abdominal cramps, and severe weakness which might lead to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Acute heart failure
diagnoses.description: Dyspnea and wheezing might occur due to the heart's inability to pump blood efficiently, sometimes accompanied by hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Symptoms can include hypotension, a sunburn-like rash, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting or diarrhea, potentially resembling abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal perforation
diagnoses.description: A hole that develops through the whole wall of the gastrointestinal tract. Symptoms can include severe abdominal cramps and may lead to hypotension due to infection or shock.

diagnoses.name: Severe sepsis
diagnoses.description: A significant infection that spreads throughout the body can lead to a systemic inflammatory response, causing hypotension, abdominal cramps, and possibly incontinence due to severe illness.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylactic shock
diagnoses.description: Similar to anaphylaxis, this is an extreme, life-threatening allergic reaction. Symptoms include severe hypotension, dyspnea, wheezing, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary embolism
diagnoses.description: A blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in your lungs. Symptoms can include dyspnea, chest pain, and in severe cases, hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Cholinergic crisis
diagnoses.description: Excessive activation of the parasympathetic nervous system, which can lead to symptoms like abdominal cramps, increased body secretions (potentially leading to incontinence), hypotension, and breathing difficulties.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble speaking, and loss of balance or coordination.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms are similar to a stroke and include paralysis or numbness on one side of the body, slurred speech, and vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms can include weakness, numbness, and, in severe cases, speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can vary greatly and can include numbness, speech difficulties, and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves neurological symptoms such as changes in vision, sensory disturbances, and speech difficulties in addition to or preceding the headache phase. These can mimic stroke-like symptoms including weakness and numbness on one side and speech difficulty.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency is a condition resulting from a reduction in blood flow to the back region of the brain, which is supplied by the vertebral and basilar arteries. Symptoms can include dizziness (vertigo), difficulty speaking (dysarthria), double vision, and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body. In its early stages, it can resemble symptoms such as weakness and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. It leads to muscle weakness, speech difficulties, and severe disability.

diagnoses.name: Bell's Palsy
diagnoses.description: Bell's palsy is a condition that causes a temporary weakness or paralysis of the muscles in the face. It can lead to drooping of the face, difficulty smiling, and closing the eye on the affected side. In some cases, it may cause numbness and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: Acoustic neuroma is a noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain. Because branches of this nerve directly influence your balance and hearing, pressure from an acoustic neuroma can cause hearing loss, ringing in your ear, and unsteadiness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraines can lead to aura, which might explain symptoms like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, whose symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision, and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, and difficulties with vision and balance, including vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. It can cause sudden headache, dizziness, and weakness, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. Brain tumors can cause headaches, weakness, vertigo, and visual disturbances like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include vertigo, dizziness, severe headache, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In some cases, patients might experience headaches and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An acute inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. This condition can cause severe headaches, weakness, and vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Glaucoma
diagnoses.description: A group of eye conditions that can cause blindness by damaging the optic nerve, the health of which is vital for good vision. This damage is often caused by abnormally high pressure in the eye and can lead to symptoms including blurring of vision and visual disturbances like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Posterior Circulation Ischemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which there is insufficient blood flow to the posterior parts of the brain including the occipital lobes, cerebellum, and brain stem, leading to symptoms including vertigo, headache, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including headaches, visual disturbances like scotoma, and sometimes weakness and auditory phenomena like tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inner ear disorder that may lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Meniere's disease affects only one ear and can also cause tinnitus and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on its location, it may cause headaches, weakness, tinnitus, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include weakness, visual disturbances, and sometimes tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, and depending on the area of the brain affected, visual and auditory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure can lead to various symptoms, including headaches and occasional auditory symptoms like tinnitus if it leads to complications affecting the brain or ears.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, often in the head, which can decrease the blood flow to the brain and eyes, causing headaches, visual disturbances, and occasionally tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can cause weakness, headaches, and sometimes tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Traumatic Brain Injury
diagnoses.description: Injury to the brain from an external force. Can lead to a wide range of symptoms such as headaches, weakness, problems with vision, and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor that develops on the cranial nerve that runs from the brain to the inner ear and controls balance and hearing. Symptoms may include hearing loss and tinnitus in one ear, along with dizziness and balance problems.

diagnoses: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) with autoimmune complications
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, considering a broad differential diagnosis)
